assumption: Proline substitutions are the optimal approach for prefusion stabilization of coronavirus spike proteins
hypothesis: Systematic cavity-filling mutations using hydrophobic residues can achieve superior stability while maintaining conformational flexibility compared to rigid proline substitutions
impact: Could provide more stable immunogens without conformational rigidity, potentially improving cross-variant immunity and establishing alternative design paradigms
evidence: Wu et al. (2023) identified multiple effective non-proline stabilizing mutations through systematic screening, directly supporting alternative mechanisms beyond proline paradigm

assumption: Maximum rigidity in prefusion state equals optimal immunogenicity
hypothesis: Controlled conformational dynamics within the prefusion state enhance immune recognition better than static fixation
impact: Could explain reduced immunogenicity in some highly stabilized variants and guide next-generation vaccine design principles
evidence: Riley et al. (2021) showed enhanced immunogenicity with extreme stabilization, contradicting over-stabilization concerns. McCallum et al. (2020) provides tools to test static vs dynamic states directly

assumption: Stabilizing individual spike protein domains independently is sufficient for optimal vaccine performance
hypothesis: Engineering cooperative stabilization networks across multiple domains yields synergistic stability improvements with fewer mutations
impact: Could achieve better stability while maintaining inter-domain communication critical for function and antigenicity
evidence: Riley et al. (2021) demonstrated synergistic effects of multiple complementary stabilization mechanisms. Wu et al. (2023) revealed multiple S2 domain sites contributing to stability

assumption: Universal stabilization strategies work equally well across all SARS-CoV-2 variants
hypothesis: Identifying variant-specific destabilization patterns enables targeted, more effective stabilization strategies than one-size-fits-all approaches
impact: Could provide framework for rapidly adapting vaccine designs to emerging variants and improving variant-specific immunity
evidence: Hsieh et al. (2020) demonstrated need for virus-specific optimization beyond simple assumption transfer from related coronaviruses

assumption: Thermal stability (melting temperature) is the best predictor of vaccine antigen performance and clinical efficacy
hypothesis: Functional stability metrics (receptor binding retention, conformational integrity under physiological stress) better predict immunogenic success than thermal measurements
impact: Could redirect stabilization efforts toward clinically relevant stability measures and improve vaccine efficacy predictions
evidence: Thermal stability often measured in non-physiological conditions; functional stability under storage/physiological conditions may be more predictive

assumption: Any transition toward post-fusion conformations is detrimental and should be completely eliminated through stabilization
hypothesis: Controlled, limited exposure of conserved post-fusion epitopes enhances breadth of immune response against variants
impact: Could provide broader protection against variant escape and improve universal vaccine design strategies
evidence: Post-fusion epitopes are often highly conserved across variants; strategic exposure could enhance cross-protection

assumption: Static high-resolution structures provide sufficient information for optimal rational stabilization design
hypothesis: Incorporating protein dynamics and allosteric networks into design algorithms yields superior stabilization strategies compared to structure-only approaches
impact: Could unlock stabilization approaches invisible to structure-only analysis and improve rational design success rates
evidence: Dynamic effects and allosteric networks are not captured in static structures but may be critical for stabilization

assumption: Over-stabilization of viral fusion proteins reduces immunogenicity by constraining conformational flexibility
hypothesis: Maximum thermodynamic stabilization enhances rather than compromises immunogenicity by maintaining proper antigen presentation
impact: Could guide design of next-generation vaccines toward maximum rather than moderate stabilization approaches
evidence: Riley et al. (2021) experimental data directly contradicts over-stabilization assumption, showing enhanced immunogenicity with extreme stabilization

assumption: Stabilization strategies developed in mammalian expression systems can be universally applied across all platforms
hypothesis: Platform-specific stabilization strategies optimized for different expression systems (bacterial, yeast, plant) yield superior results than universal approaches
impact: Could enable broader vaccine manufacturing options and reduce production costs while maintaining or improving efficacy
evidence: Different expression systems have varying post-translational modifications, folding environments, and cellular stress conditions requiring tailored approaches

assumption: Laboratory thermal stability automatically translates to manufacturing stability and scalability
hypothesis: Manufacturing-specific stress conditions (shear, pH, freeze-thaw) require distinct stabilization approaches beyond simple thermal stability
impact: Could prevent production bottlenecks and enable more robust global vaccine distribution networks
evidence: Manufacturing processes involve stresses not captured by standard thermal stability assays

assumption: Stabilization mutations do not significantly impact immunodominance hierarchies or epitope accessibility
hypothesis: Systematic preservation of key epitope accessibility during stabilization design enhances protective immunity compared to stability-only optimization
impact: Could maintain or enhance vaccine effectiveness while achieving superior stability profiles
evidence: Stabilization could inadvertently mask protective epitopes or alter immune recognition patterns

assumption: Single stabilization strategies work equally well across all storage and distribution conditions
hypothesis: Adaptive stabilization networks that respond differently to various environmental stresses provide superior protection than static approaches
impact: Could enable room-temperature stable vaccines for global distribution without cold chain infrastructure requirements
evidence: Different storage conditions may trigger distinct degradation pathways requiring condition-specific responses

assumption: Maximum stabilization always correlates with optimal vaccine performance in a linear relationship
hypothesis: There exists an optimal stabilization zone that balances stability with immunogenic presentation, beyond which additional stabilization provides diminishing returns
impact: Could guide design principles to avoid over-stabilization while achieving necessary stability for clinical applications
evidence: May be threshold effects where excessive stabilization begins to impair immune recognition or vaccine efficacy
